Name: Biocentrism: How Life and Consciousness are the Keys to Understanding the True Nature of the Universe

ReviewList.Text: I am a fan of Dr. Lanza's blogs on the Huffington Post and decided to buy his book.  I was not disappointed.  What a wonderful book, not only for the groundbreaking idea he posits but also for his beautiful prose style of writing.  How refreshing it is to encounter a scientist unafraid to challenge our perceptions and go against the tide bringing us a fresh perspective on old puzzles.  Indeed it answers many conundrums that Physicists have traditionally ignored.  Why indeed are the laws of nature balanced so precisely to afford our existence?  Is biocentrism the answer that has been tugging at the edges of our understanding for so long?  Who can deny that Dr. Lanza may be on to something here?

I'm a little surprised to see such a variance in ratings for this, but I suspect it may be more from people resisting some of the ideas instead of simply enjoying the discussion. Robert Lanza is obviously very talented and smart, and he is a great person to learn more about - so take the time to expose yourself to all of the work he has published, including other books/articles and his website/twitter feed. I enjoyed this book mainly because it was a great way to open my mind to alternative thoughts and theories about reality and our experience of life. I never approach material like this with any preconceived notions - I just love to see what great thinkers have to say and I try to stay open-minded about things that may seem "out there" to others. He mixes science with some personal stories as he explains his theories, and you can tell he relishes his role of challenging the establishment (mainly the physics community as a whole) while he does this. I enjoyed every page and I look forward to keeping up with the future works from a true maverick of thought like Dr. Lanza.

As a mathematically challenged non-scientist, quantum mechanics will always be a mystery to me.  But at least the book, Biocentrism, has put even my limited intellect right smack in the middle of everything.  Why, heck, I might even be integral to the Grand Unified Theory of the Universe.  If I don't look out at the cosmos, it isn't there!  Don't worry; I'll be sure to glance upward every night just so the stars don't blink out. Biocentrism, as expected, provides almost no answers, but the new questions it asks are . . . fascinating.

Lanza's unchallengable scientific qualifications along with his sometimes surprising humanity make this a memorable and beautiful book. Quantum Physics is a hobby of mine and I have read several books (as well as taking college courses) on the subject. Much of the theory and experiments described were quite familiar to me but the authors give some a new slant. I found the book mostly to offer a most hopeful explanation of the mysteries of this life that we all find ourselves so involved in. I LOVED this book.
Personal philosophy disguised as science. Provocative but ultimately just another crackpot take on a bunch of profound questions. Don't bother.

Author Robert Lanza MD has, since childhood, sought out and been mentored by Nobel Laureates and it shows.  His radical presentation of the last 50-70 years of quantum physics research and the significance of that research takes us beyond where The Tao of Physics and others started.  His clear readable text (combined with some amazing personal stories of his colorful and dysfunctional upbringing) brings us face to face with the fact that science, like conventional religion, has an "edge" beyond which nothing is understood - like "why are we here?" or "what happened before the Big Bang?"  A beautiful, hopeful, and brilliant case for consciousness underlying all of Creation, told from the scientific point of view.  Great read!

This is one of the most important books written in a good long while. For over 100 years quantum physics has sat balanced and unresolved, ready to fall on the side of classical physics and materialism, or to finally embrace to resolve the quantum enigma that life presented. The classical school anachronists, despite unparalleled advances in all other scientific fields, haven’t had the wherewithal – primarily scientific courage – to confront the challenge of moving this field forward. Well, Robert Lanza has brilliantly confronted this, to make probably the most significant advance in the last forty years. It would naturally take someone who possesses both scientific acumen and spiritual acuity to pull this off. In retrospect it is clear that the answer couldn’t come from hard science alone, but would require a tremendously high polymath mind to blend in the necessary component of spiritual philosophy - after all, it was the life ingredient they couldn't think with. A scientific centrism bereft of the bio, not only makes us a cosmic joke and a relatively impossible dice throw, but is also pointless. And he presents this tectonic shift of thought with an astonishing form of academic grace. If Einstein had been born again in this new age where such ideas are (barely) acceptable, and written his theorems in a new type of scientific poetry to incorporate life, it would have to be similar to Biocentrism. (Makes you wonder about reincarnation.)

This is a book I want to read again.  I enjoyed it, and went back and re-read a few sections before I even finished.  Some of the ideas in it are very well presented, and some not so well, and yes, it is soft on the science.  I can't fault it for that, however.  There's a lot going on here, and it's up to the reader to follow up on the pieces that catch his/her fancy.  The point of the book, I think, is to get the reader thinking in a new direction.  I, for one, don't have a solid background in hard science, although I am the sort that picks up and reads pretty much anything so I do have a broad background.  Delving too deeply into the science would have made the book unreadable except to those with the right sort of education -- I don't think that is the only intended audience.  I also found the mini-autobiography that is woven into the text interesting.  I kept waiting for it to tie a bit more securely into the theoretical portion of the text, but that never really happened.  It did break up the mind-bending theorizing, humanize the authors, and perhaps make the book more readable, but it also padded the content to make it look more substantial. It's the sort of book I want to give to my friends just so we can discuss it.

First off, let us consider that Dr. Robert Lanza is one of the most well respected and well known scientists in the world, and yet seems to be able to simplify this elegant theory into something we can all understand.. And even more, something we can not avoid. He offers a perspective very different from what we've all been taught and challenges us to step outside of the box and dismiss conventional wisdom in order to fully comprehend his central thesis.. That life creates the universe, not the other way around. He insists that Physics will keep falling flat on its head when searching for a unifying theory unless they incorporate consciousness into the equation. Sound far fetched?? Not when he brakes down the basics of his theory with a style and flare that I wish my High School science teacher had. He never fails to be informative while entertaining all at once. Sure to be regarded as a classic, and even more impressive that for once we get an honest explaination of the universe and our role in it.. From the mind of a Biologist, not a Physicist!!

This theory seemed so outlandish that it just kept gnawing at me until I gave it a try. I came away from this book thinking that Robert Lanza is onto something here. With brilliant anecdotes, illustrations, and wonderful personal stories, Robert Lanza presents his case beautifully that creation exists because we are here to observe it. Confusing? At the subatomic level particles only exist as potential energy unless being observed. He had me thinking that my refrigerator does not exist if I am upstairs sleeping and not observing it. This theory is given credence by some seemingly convincing scientific experiments. I gave it 4 stars because Lanza promises in the beginning of the book not to intermingle God in his theory and then proceeds to give some explanations on how a star was observed over a certain baby in a manger. Otherwise it is a fascinating read and was certainly written for the layperson.
This book took me on a much deeper journey than I set out for. Not all science, the book poses the most profound questions we never ask.
Fascinating book! a scientific exploration of consciousness linked to the theory of everything living. Also  illustrated with a personal and poetic narrations of Lanza's personal experiences.

The central theme of this book is that life creates the universe and that consciousness lies at the center of existence. This is not a new idea and there is absolutely nothing new in this book. Lanza draws on two main sources to back up this idea. The first is that consciousness appears to cause the wave function to collapse in the famous double slit experiment. The second concerns the anthropic principle and how it seems that universe is uncannily just right for life. Both of these 'proofs' are open to various interpretations including the possibility that consciousness does indeed lie at the center of creation. However, that is only one possible conclusion that can be drawn and Lanza adds absolutely zero to the debate. He uses his book to lambaste physics and physicists for such like as not being able to tell us what came before the big bang, whilst at the same time declaring consciousness to be the be all and end all of everything without actually defining what consciousness is or offering any sort of explanation of how it came into existence or how it creates the physical universe. On top of that much of the book contains sections that have absolutely nothing to do with the subject matter and concern nothing more than Lanza's own life experiences. He uses these chapters to butter his own biscuit, blast his own trumpet and bang his own drum interspersed with a bit of name dropping. The worst book I've read all year!

I found the relationship of consciousness to the universe intriguing. But I found his criticism of string theory as speculative somewhat inconsistent, given that this theory is also speculative. I do think that consciousness is one of those mysteries that is tied up with other aspects of the universe, but I don't necessarily accept that the rest of the universe exists only as probabilities until perceived by a conscious entity. I find research into near-death experiences also very intriguing, and I was somewhat surprised that no reference was made to that research here. Still, this is a good read, and I recommend it.

Unless I read this book wrong, Lanza appears to be using the premise that perception is relative to say that existence doesn't exist except in our consciousness.  While I strongly agree with the premise, I don't see how the conclusion follows.  If a tree falls in the woods, just because we aren't around to translate the changes in air pressure into sound doesn't mean that the tree didn't create these changes in air pressure, and it definitely doesn't mean that the tree doesn't exist.  I enjoyed learning about the author's life, but I don't enjoy that he apparently ignored bodies of research from both perception and consciousness studies.  He answers "consciousness" without going in to what that might be.  Anyhow, kudos for challenging classical physics with quantum mechanics, but that new age boat left many years ago, making this book nothing new.

ok I'm down with this idea, that the physical universe is evolved from consciousness but this book could have been condensed to a few pages - yes, physics has entered the realm of the nonprovable but so is this theory - yes, you can ask what happened before the big bang but you can also ask what happened before consciousness - the premise 'biology is primary' has been around for several millennia - this book is 95% why current thought won't arrive at the ultimate answer' but this book provides no alternative to derive the answers that conventional scientific thought is struggling with - human evolution has always had to take into account unanswered questions - the real question is whether the questions themselves can ever be answered or are we confined to a lineage of paradigm shifts

Honestly, I didn't understand a lot about quantum physics before I read this book.  I think I know have only a very basic understanding of the implications of this field of research - even after reading the book.  But the book opened my eyes to not well understood questions our research has brought up, and it facinated me.  I think Lanza has dared to propose a theory that explains what science has demonstrated - and if he is right, it has far-reaching implications -- and possibilities.  Thrilling and fascinating!

This is an extraordinary book for individuals with the intellectual skills required to analyze Dr. Lanza's and Dr. Berman's theories, in a logical and open fashion.  I would strongly urge you to first read the book Quantum Enigma by the physicists, Bruce Rosenblum Phd and Fred Kuttner Phd, PRIOR to reading Biocentrism, as it will give you a grounded NO-nonsense description of the "quantum strangeness" in physics that Dr. Lanza and Dr. Berman are discribing in their book. I especially want to complement Dr. Lanza for his courage in sharing the "emotionally difficult" stories from his personal life. Both Dr. Lanza and Dr. Berman are highly respected scientists which lends great credabilty to their theories expounded in Biocentrism

I'm no quantum physicist but think Lanza has shared what is a complicated reality check on "reality" in the simplest way. It makes sense to me, much more sense than any of the theories or hypothesis of the beginning of everything and our place in it that I've ever heard. If you stop, breathe and think about his assertion, it's not such a big step to take to switch things around and say? "Yeah I get it and it just makes sense." Thank you Robert, life changing.

Have given it to several friends after receiving it from a friend on the board of the most prestigious theoretical think tank in the country.  All agree it should be required reading for anyone who hopes/dispairs for the future.

Blew my mind on several occasions.  I wonder how the author feels about common human desires, such as the desire to be popular or gain fame.  Based on biocentrism, it seems as though fame is sought after by people to validate one's own existence--if you exist in the minds of many, you somehow exist more than if, say, only your parents know you.

Robert Lanza's expert review of the central role of consciousness in shaping not only our understanding of the universe but actually in creating the universe, by making links between the implications of quantum mechanics and biology, returns life and spirit to the centrepoint of our understanding and at the secret heart of the universe.  The implications of this book - that consciousness along with matter is fundamental to properti, ies of the universe, that consciousness is not a mere byproduct or epiphenomenon, is staggering in its implications.  Nevertheless, this view is not quirky but based on a solid foundation of science and has been implied ever since newtonian mechanics began to become rapidly qualified by quantum mechanics in the 20th Century.  Most scientists have been reluctant to face the philosophical implications of their own fundamental findings, but the frontiers of physics have produced an increasing number of scientists who are doing so, and returning consciousness to the centre of the universe.  It is relatively unusual, however, to find a biologist who appreciates the positive implications of this for their own field;  biologists tends to be positivists, witness their strong presence in New Atheism.  Lanza's book is part of a  growing coherence in the new consciousness-centred scientific view of the universe, whose outlook, strengthened by a solid and repeatedly verified corpus of experimental evidence, is likely to supplant the current positivist view over the next century.  As physicist Amit Goswami points out, this altered outlook has profound implications for values and civilisation.  Since tin physicshe nineteenth century, a paradigm based on positivism in physics and neo-darwinism in biology has produced ideologies and outlooks justifying a dominance of the strong over the weak and the elimination of the latter. It has also resulted in a weakening of social values, also linked to the 'death' of God, as Nietschke predicted would happen, since morality no longer looks to a higher authority than ourselves.  The new science does not return us to the biblical God, but rather, in broad resonance with oriental mysticism and shamanism, guides us towards a property of Mind at the heart of nature, and by doing so, provides the tools to review the values and goals of the human racecentred on spirituality, not on materialism, but this time based not on the authority of ancient books but that of science.  Surely, for the modern world, this emergent scientific view will prove to be the soundest guide to a regenerated human civilisation which has understandably discarded the old books but has not found a new  guide to how we should live and what we should believe.  In this regard, I believe Lanza's book is one of the most important and instructive in recent times.

I've heard bits and pieces of similar theories before, but I will stamp this book with the same moniker I give to a great movie or simply a great experience: it made me think. A lot. It will take time to process. And that's a good thing. It's definitely worth your time.

Extremely interesting book!  How do you merge George Berkeleys idealism (does a tree falling in a forest makes a noise if you are not there: answer: not), with stem cell research, and quantum physics, well, he does it very well. Fascinating.

I've taken a few half-hearted forays into quantum physics in the past, only to fizzle out after the whole wave-or-particle topic seemed to lead nowhere.  This book revealed a significance to that discovery by incorporating the concept of consciousness and an observer created universe.  Finally, I thought, that makes sense!  I've also delved into some of the 'spirituality' based philosophies which incorporate quantum physics and found them to feel mostly as if grasping at straws to propagate their guru-building machines.  This book brought the concept of spirituality out of the ether and into the real, individual, living realm of perception and experience.  What a fascinating new theory with which to attempt to view life and the universe!  I won't pretend to have grasped every concept here fully, but even with the basic gist, I found myself viewing myself, life and the world around me in a refreshingly new way.  This book I believe will leave the reader who is open to it feeling as if there is a familiarity to its ideas, both in the rejection of a random, dead universe, and in the innate sense that the universe is not only subjective, but subjectively created.  I hope the authors are correct that biocentrism does build momentum into a much needed life-based paradigm shift in attempting to explain the universe.  PS I am no scientist, just a regular guy, and I found this book for the most part to be very clear and understandable without the common talking-down-to language of many science or medical texts.  Highly recommended!

A fascinating journey. It challenges your thinking, beliefs and understanding of the universe. It's a book to read slowly and to read with an open mind. It offers another version of the universe and its not a bad alternative.

I re-read this book some years after pondering over the concept of biocentrism and reading other related texts. Now I see where I have gotten some of my beliefs from. Consciousness creates everything we sense; life is subjective. There is still the question of why most of us experience the same sensations, like the taste of different foods, the sight of a loved one face, etc. There has to be an agreement of some kind that is in effect that delineates what we're supposed to experience when certain stimuli occurs. I know for certain that God is because of many miracles I've personally experienced and witnessed. I believe that God is the glue that holds everything together. I also believe with the authors that free will is questionable at best. I've experienced finding out about situations years before they actually happened to me. That has led me to believe that everything is predetermined, waiting for us to experience them. Why the absence of free will freaks people out is beyond me; I take comfort in it because if I have a problem the solution is also present already before the problem even occurred. This is an excellent book; it should be required reading by everyone, including scientists.

The book goes into interesting paradoxes and uses quantum observations to support its theory. However most of the book is rambling, and goofy set ups for ponderous metaphors. For someone with his credentials I was expecting more convincing hypothesis. Overall this was a waste of time.
An incredibly well written and lucid prose that had me glued to every word.  Lanza successfully fuses the mysterious unknown to scientific inquiry!

I have often wondered what it would have been like in the time of Copernicus to tell your mates at the pub that the earth may well be round. I can image those friends telling me not to be an idiot. Everybody knows its flat, sits on an elephant that sits on a turtle. The people on the bottom would fall off if it was round. "What are you thinking?" Be careful you might get burnt at the stake for talking like this. It has made me speculate what is our current "flat world" of this new century. Lanzas wonderful book may well have described it for me. Why cant science explain what was before the big bang? Why did it happen? What exactly is it expanding into? Why hasnt it stopped expanding when their mathematics tells us it should? Why cant science explain consciousness when all of us know it exists. Well written, thought provoking and has given me my "Flat World" moment.

I was honored to have Dr. Robert Lanza as a guest on my show. He is simultaneously brilliant, soulful and articulate. He takes what I think of as a pretty challenging topic, namely how the universe works, and explains it; not bad for only 207 pages! He picks up where traditional thought has failed us and kicks some serious scientific butt! It's total brain candy!

You know how when you go to sleep the world, for you, goes away? It really doesn't exist for that period of time you're asleep, right? We all just assume everything goes on without us for that period of time because people tell us so. Robert Lanza takes that simple concept to an extreme. This is a fascinating book but it will take a person with a wide open mind to be able to sink teeth into. He asserts that time and space are constructs of the mind and do not, cannot, exist without consciousness perceiving them, that if all human and animal life should vanish, so would the universe. It would cease to exist as well. I recommend that you buy this book, read it for yourself and let Dr. Lanza explain it to you. It's a fascinating take on the existence of... everything.
This is going down as one of the most important books of the 21st century and it is amazingly well written.

The validation of "the biology of everything" is heartening and welcomed!  In healing work I look to "shifting the biology" in the client and that is always done with facilitating forth consciousness to accommodate a fuller understanding of the whole situation.  The book is a quiet yet profound "landing", pulling all the parts together and in a firm but gentle way, seeing the procession that we are a part of, moving ahead now with inclusion of all of the possibilities of all the sciences under the direction of our consciousness.

Lanza does a good job in gathering current data from science to support what has already been understood by Eastern thought and Western Mysticism. If most westerners were not so scared of studying the ancient mystery traditions as "devil worship" they would uncover that mystics have been saying the same thing for thousands of years. Read about the structure of consciousness in Buddhist psychology. Read about the Kabbalah especially the part that examines the four worlds and human consciousness. It is all there.

This book is written in a reader friendly manner.  But the contents will jostle the belief systems of many of its readers. Biocentrism is just what the word implies. It is biology, notably human consciousness. that is the creative center of the universe. Lanza's scientific credentials are impeccable, but his ideas would shock B.F. Skinner and many of his other mentors.

Robert Lanza might have just layed out the groundwork for some of the principles behind what we call reality. A mesmerizing text, written in layman's terms. There very few books that I tell myself I have to read more than once...this is one of those books. If you're interesting in what human consciousness means, this is a theory that makes total sense.
excellent and timely, this is perhaps the single most important  book I have read. After years of puzzling 'quantum' theory, I GET IT!

An excellent book! An eye opener to possibility! Well-written and accessible to a general audience without a science background, the book still stays with the facts of what we now know to be true about quantum mechanics. I highly recommend this book to anyone who is seriously interested in the deeper nature of reality.

Fascinating to the core. a real eye opener about why we absolutely must change our way of thinking on mental health issues and take positive action. I am an athiest so the spipitual epilogue didn't gell for me, however the research and discoveries about cellular structure have changed my view of life forever.

Absolutely interesting, thoughtful and a reading must.  However, there are entire chapters dedicated to maudlin reminiscences of personal memories which are totally out of place.  Incomprenhible how the editors allowed that material to be included in this extraordinary book.

Funny that Lanza is saying what Buddha said 2000 years ago, what L. Ron Hubbard said 60 years ago, what Fritoj Capra, Rupert Sheldrake & David Bohm all said 25 years ago. I guess any idea can be repackaged. The real key is getting the rest of humanity to realize these truths.

In simple words, Lanza explains how the world is based on our perception and perception alone. The current science is showing that the current worldview of the universe is fundamentally flawed. It is a must read book for everyone. Very logical, wonderfully written.

This concept fits nicely with personal theories on which 've ruminated for many years.  The authors personal anecdotes were necessarily illustrative.  I'll possibly return to give this tome 5 stars should a sequel, if at all planned, provide updated knowledge ...

Every now and then a great mind sees the world differently and has the rare skill of being able to write about it lucidly enough that common (read: average) brains can understand.  The ideas of this book are a real joy and eye opener.  I loved this book.
If you are not able to think for yourself, don't even bother.  Some of the ideas presented here are unsettling, but worth listening to.  A biologist explaining physics is an interesting approach!
A can't put it down kind of book. Shows how one can rise above even the most miserable of circumstances and rise to greatness as did this author. Makes a really good gift.  Rosemary Salinas

`By striving to see through the veil of our ordinary perceptions, we can come closer to understanding our profound relationship to all created things'. So says acclaimed physician and life researcher Robert Lanza. In his book, Biocentrism, he has perhaps brought the reader a step or two closer to that kind of understanding.  Lanza shows that theoretical physicists, who dominate the grand search for a unified theory of life, may well be overreaching in the wrong direction. Biocentrism makes a compelling case that the consciousness that each of us as humans takes for granted is creating its own reality. While concepts like the quantum wave-particle duality and the Schrodinger's Cat paradox play a part in Lanza's presentation, the elements of his own personal story that are woven through this book help very much to make it accessible and deeply engaging. Lanza sees the ultimate mystery of consciousness as the essence of Biocentrism. Our physical bodies inevitably die away but, perhaps in the form of pure consciousness, we as conscious entities merely move on to a new reality. Lanza's message is heartfelt and life affirming, and also grounded convincingly in science...at least that which is knowable.  Scared of the grim reaper? Biocentrism may be the right antidote.
Excellent book! Very accessible for people who are not scientists.Well written. Exciting points. Illustrates what a profound and wondrous time it is for us to be alive on this planet.
I appreciate that these are Interesting and inspiring theories given by a renown scientist.  His viewpoints offer a new way of looking at consciousness and life.  I was enthralled.
Wow - this book is shaking my understanding of the Universe - and thank you for doing so! The style is easy to follow with clear explanations on complex scientific concepts.

Lanza follows up implications in the quantum enigma of consciousness debate with some compelling ideas of the "Of course. Why didn't I think of that?" variety. The critically fine margins for conditions favoring life in the universe are their own argument for the creative role of consciousness in bringing form and substance to what is otherwise wave function potential. Lanza has an impressive scientific background, but his book is highly accessible to the average reader, generally free of impenetrable scientific jargon and made relevant to the common world of feelings and sentiment. His quotes from Emerson and Thoreau to illustrate points of biocentric theory are revelatory and startling in their aptness in explaining aspects of current quantum thought. I found Biocentrism to be a rich and hopeful book permeated with the consoling perception of an intimately personal universe that is not "out there" and to be feared, but within ourselves and tailored to our needs.
This book was everything I hoped it would be. A great read. It makes total sense. I will read other books by this author and recommend him to my friends as well.
As a lay person without the education to truly understand what was written, I was nevertheless able to understand enough that I want to read and learn more.
His poor writing gets a bit in the way of his ideas, but this book does much to further the vision and acceptance of a monumentally new (and old) paradigm.

The authors make a strong argument for their theory which is derived primarily from the famous "double slit" experiments within quantum physics, and which includes the impact of consciousness on the "material" universe. Although I thought I possessed a strong understanding of modern physics - including quantum mechanics - this book reinvented that understanding; broadening and deepening my understanding of how this universe works. What better knowledge is there to possess than that? It may be counter-intuitive, but biocentrism is the best theory there is for explaining how the universe works. This book lays out a strong argument for why one should believe the authors' views on the subject. You'll love it and will be thankful you invested your time into something so fundamental as understanding the universe!

The book was true to the expectations created by the marketing guys. Simply makes an excellent case for the need for the previously missing element of consciousness when speculating on theories of creation of the universe. Pretty well discounts the Big Band theory and makes the case for universal design being based on consciousness, since without it, the universe would have no meaning and could have not been designed nor function as it does. Lanza is an entertaining writer with some clever tongue in cheek scattered throughout, and does well at introducing himself and his own personal history and credentials while focusing on the principles presented. Well worth the read. I will be re-visiting these pages from time to time to further stimulate my own thoughts and feelings, to which he contributes amazingly well.
Explained in easy to understand terms. Now I have to find out more about Quantum theory!  I highly recommend it.

Not being academic, I wondered how I would cope with this book, particularly because I only remember the fundamentals of classical physics from high school. I won't pretend to say I fully understand all the science in his book, however, he explains himself so well (with a wit unusual in a serious scientist)that I was able to get a grip on his work.  It is so utterly interesting and refreshing and of course as a respected scientist he has his reputation at stake. He certainly makes you think and re-think everything you thought you knew, and there is an honesty in his work. Of course, we are not in possession of all the answsers to the Universe and Mr Lanza does not pretend to have them all, but as Tim Freke would say, "The Mystery of it all is so exciting."  Robert Lanza confirms this opinion.

I wanted to like--LOVE--this book. And in some measure I did. The pushback on recent cosmological hubris and insistence on a little more humility was a breath of fresh air. The delving into variations of the double slit experiment were mind numbing (and worth the read in themselves, actually). But time again, much like the quantum uncertainty it relies on entirely, its quality was in wave form. It never took shape despite this observers continual desire to effect such a state. I ended up walking away disappointed in investing as much time as I did with so little payoff. Winding narratives that are pointless, increasingly more reliant upon Thoreau and Emerson and poetic storytelling, and dwindling scientific substance of any sort the book faded away into more hippie and less helpful.

Biocentrism by Robert Lanza and Bob Berman is truly an unexpected journey into the aspects of reality above time and beyond space; a scientific approach to why we CANNOT die that is a must read for anyone who fears death or has been indoctrinated by the reductionists. This easy to read text explains quantum  physics in simple language then mixes it with biocentrism to weave the story of the entire universe in terms of consciousness and observation. As complocated as this may sound, Lanza and Berman have the knack of penning their work in ways that are simply darn enjoyable to read and absolutely informative. It's a make-you-think-and-feel experience that can change your enire view of life after life.

Biocentrism is a difficult book to understand its premise. I don't believe the authors ever make it clear how life and consciousness are the keys to understanding the universe. It's a kind of the chicken before the egg or the other way around with no answers for the unanswerable. The theory of biocentrism as the an answer does no more for me than gods, an intelligent designer, or ant other theories. One thing the authors do bring out is the great question of how our world is so planned for life existence, but is biocentrism really a clear answer?

I bought this and Peter Ralston's book because of the emphasis on Consciousness.  What caught my attention was a comment that we really may not die, but that consciousness goes on forever and the idea that the universe is created out of consciousness.  I am a Jungian Psychotherrapist and much of this was not news, but I must say that the way he approaches the topic of consiousness was elucidating.  It has started me thinking about Consciousness vs Unconscious is a significant way.  Relative to what I shared above, it really is not all that simple!  But opens the Doors of Perception to a different way.  Gary W. Mac Kendrick

I was impressed with the spirituality of Dr. Lanza's interpretation of reality. He makes it reality consciousness evolving and doesn't make the mistake of giving all impetus the outside or material causes. His view is a blending of the two: outer and inner. I like how he intersperses the theory with tales of his horrific childhood but not as a victim. His heart is focused on his older sister, who cared for him and was a port in the storm, and then a ship who went down herself. Somehow he managed to escape (the only word for it) the minimalist upbringing to blossom into a very useful individual.

I was intrigued by the premise of this book (that biology, rather than other sciences such as physics, will reveal the nature of reality). I don't have a strong background in science, but I enjoy science books that are accessible. This book can be enjoyed by scientists and lay people alike. It challenges conventional thought about the nature of the universe, consciousness, and spiritual concerns. It will "blow your mind" if you take the time to absorb the ideas. I like this kind of experience and recommend it.

Not sure I 'buy' the concept but Lanza lays out an argument for consciousness as a condition for the existence of the universe as we perceive it. He does a good job of deconstructing how we use our senses to define the universe, and ties quantum mechanic conundrums to the role of the conscious observer.  Lanza maintains space, time, and perception are constructs of consciousness.  On the downside he criticizes science for using theories such as string theory,which can not be tested, to build a 'theory of everything', but  proposes a new paradigm which is also beyond proof.

This book is for anyone who has an open mind and who questions the current scientific paradigm of describing the universe and our place in it, and who is not afraid to entertain the possibility that our current scientific idea of what constitutes the "stuff" of reality may be completely erroneous.  This is a great book as it confirms for me what I've always suspected is the true nature of reality, as I have thought of the impossibility of anything existing outside of consciousness, so I heartily recommend this book to anyone who wants to expand their view of the universe.

Dr. Lanza's philosophy of the nature of the universe is fascinating.  He supports his ideas using quantum based science but doesn't go quite far enough in answering some of the glaring questions associated with his ideas.  What he does put forth entices the reader to reconsider their view of the world by considering reality within rather from outside the world of our own consciousness.  Some concepts are difficult to wrap the mind around but force one to actively read and ponder his conclusions.  What it still does not answer for me is the question of WHY am I ME.

Great insight into some of the issues, but fails to address others.  For example, while space is recognized to be a function of consciousness, what about matter?  Does Berkeley have it right after all?  And Lanza periodically attributes the source of consciousness to the brain.  But whether that is the case, vs. the brain being another 'thing' within awareness is never clearly addressed.  Dr. Lanza would do well to read (and reference) Douglas Harding).  But aside from where the "truth" lies, I greatly appreciated the book.

I want to start this out by saying that, while I am fascinated by both physics and philosophy, I am not an expert in either.  This book is easy to understand for a layperson, for the most part.  There is one chapter that is specifically devoted to quantum physics and it did go over my head a little bit.  That being said, the theory in this book is astounding but the logic is sound.  I have intuitively sensed some of this but seeing it in print and based on physics was just amazing.  I have recommended this book to several people.

I had a hard time putting this book down. Lanza and Berman are personable writers as well as being original in thought. I didn't take this as an attack on physics but rather a blending of biology and other sciences with physics. The book makes one think and is worth a re-read most definitely as I am no scientist and it takes me a while to grasp what they are saying. I won't give anything away about the book as it really should be read by those interested in the sciences. It is certainly not impossible for a non-scientist to read!

Whoever expected to laugh through a science book? Dr. Lanza is entertaining and though-provoking describing the missing link how our physical make-up and conscious awareness creates our viewpoint of reality. He is still missing God, the energy of it all, but I like the way he tells it in a language anyone can understand. I get it! I'm grateful he took the time to explain what other scientists avoid.

Finally we are moving away further from the Einsteins, Darwins and Hawkings! I think this approach, biocentrism, is preparing us for future knowledge developments. The thing is however, that it will probably take another 30 years before our kids are thaught the new knowledge in schools. The world is a slow moving animal. The book is absolutely recommended for all of us open minded people. If you are stuck in a special man made religion you will have some problems though.

Brilliant author, pushes the envelope on conventional thinking, a new wrinkle on the old saw: "If no one is there when a tree falls in the forest, would it make a sound?"  Author would say a definite "No."  You must read it to understand why that might be so.  He offers an antidote to the ambiguity and tentativeness of quantum physics and raises an implicit wonderment over "Who/What was observing as the universe began its continuing creation?"

The author takes the time to really explain how all of these quantum weirdness fits in together. The experiments related to entanglement are perfectly explained, first book that makes it clear. The idea that consciousness somehow affects physical reality is not new but some of the thought experiments and hypothesis presented in here, as far as I know, are. I am now looking for other books addressing bio-consciousness-centrism. Very interesting and an enjoyable read.

Overall a great book. The author has a great knowledge of biology and quite a good knowledge of physics. I appreciate that the book is not some "new-age" nonsense and also that it shows how LITTE we know about the universe which is a huge mystery but I didn't like the sentimental side of personal stories - they belong rather to an auto-biography than here. Anyway, for everyone, who is inclined to Zen and Advaita, this book is recommended.

The main idea has been around for quite some time, by different authors, in different disciplines. But it was useful to bring all that together under "one roof". I'm not quite clear, however, how I would have created the photons coming from outerspace and striking my retina. I was hoping also that the authors would've gotten into the area of near death experiences, or the new field of research "after-death communication".

I really liked this book a lot and would like to have given it 5 stars. However, the last 3 or 4 chapters seem somewhat disjointed - like they belong to another book, or were written for a different purpose, and left me a little disappointed. Still, the first part of the book is fantastic and definitely worth the read. I completely agree with the premise the matter is an emergent property of consciousness, and not the other way around.

I was very interested in this topic.  Lanza did a good job incorporating storytelling instead of just making this a physics book.  It was very well written, and the topic was quite intriguing.  I only gave it four stars because some points lost me in terms of continuity.  It all comes together at the end, but I don't like reading a book like this and feeling as if I missed something.  Regardless, if you're interested in this, get it.

All through my years in school and around academia they said "this" is the way it is, but over and over discoveries have proved them wrong.  This book reveals what science and particularly physics and biology are coming to:  this world that lies before us like a dream is just as substantial as a dream.  Without we the observers the "real world" would simply fade away.  Great read - It's the real deal.

This is a book with a very interesting philosophy at its centre. It is well explained, although some of the physics were a little difficult to follow. I will read it again as I felt only one reading was not enough to absorb all of the information. All in all I enjoyed the book and it gave me food for thought and I'm still thinking of the central message, and have no problem in recommending it to other readers.

Although it is well written, I feel there is more to know about biocentrism than the authors conveyed – much more.  Perhaps, over eager editing left revealing material on the cutting room floor, maybe there is simply more information than is convenient for a short volume meant for the lay public.  Whatever the reason, I plan to read it a second time and give it another review knowing what to expect.

Great book. Well written. Interesting and thought-provoking topic. Very happy I purchased and read. Its only downfall is that it doesn't go quite far enough: "Ok, so nothing is real. What next?" The authors admit they deliberately left this for others to investigate, but then, that's why I didn't give it five stars. Otherwise, it's a fantastic concept and really worth the read.

This book creates an accessible portal to quantum physics to those of us interested in metaphysics but who lack the academic pure physics exposure.  Lanza is outstanding and his theories are pragmatic.  Read this stuff because I believe you will see it again and again and again in research to come. This is a must read and it posits some very plausible and interesting theorem.

This book arrived promptly and as advertised. I have not finished reading it, but I question the author's credentials for arriving at his conclusions especially when they are stated so emphatically. I would be happier if he had said, How life and consciousness may be keys to... Having said that, I will add that the book is accessible to non-scientists.

Anyone searching for the deeper answers to life will enjoy this book. It's easy to understand, even though it might be hard to grasp for some, at least you don't need a PhD to understand what's written. I remember as a youngster thinking these same thoughts about life, and it's exciting seeing them resurface with confirmation from a great scientist.
Berman has opened my eyes to new possibilities. I'll spend much time reading more about his concepts and about the implications of quantum mechanics.

As a near-death-experiencer who does not feel that everything is explained away by "religion", I found this book very enlightening.  My experience left me feeling as though there were multiple universes with energy life forms living simultaneously across universes.  This book gives a more scientific explanation of what I experienced.

I thoroughly enjoyed this perspective of life and the universe.i loved the personal inclusions within the theories. It has caused me to read and listen to other books that deal with consciousness . It has left me with many questions regarding this . The fun is the exploration these questions have created.
Even though my understanding of physics is limited, this book intuitively resonated with me.  I found it hard to put down, and look forward to reading it again.
It's making me think and I haven't even finished it yet. Worthwhile if you really want a broad view of the world.
The authors present the concept of biocentrism in a nice, quick read.  I appreciate the topic, and I am glad to have read it - renewed my interest in neuroscience and its complexities.

This is a book I'll keep handy and revisit frequently as I stumble along towards eternity. Not at all a religious tome, but it deals with questions most often addressed by religion. I have the feeling that somewhere in these pages is a (most brief) glimpse of the face of God...Berman considers the imperative question my materialist friends have never been able to answer to my satisfaction..."explain consciousness". To that, I add "Imagine nothing".

The author is not trying to change your mind about anything.  He is simply stating his theory and I find it interesting.  It is the type of book that I will re-read soon because I have to digest what he is saying.  I will see more when I read again.  If you like to look at life differently, this book would be for you.

The old materialistic and atomistic view in science is urged to review it's paradigms; consciousness and biocentrism is a great way to start. Well written, easy to read and with a fresh approach you will enjoy.
An easy book to read.  It gave me some insight to a lot of possibilites.  It's a good book that anyone can be able to understand and learn from.
This book certainly makes you consider physics from a new viewpoint. It's general  arguments seem reasonable but I missed more explanation on the "next level down" details.

This book is a bit hard to understand at times and doesn't prove it's points with much needed additional analysis, but I could not put it down and is definitely worthy of a re-read. I recommend it to everyone who wants to explore how we biologic entities actually changes the universe we live in.

I am only half way through this very provocative writing about how it is that we see the universe, and yet I know that it deserves a five-star rating on a scale of one through five. to see how a pure scientist grapples with the concepts of consciousness is quite enjoyable. whether he knows it or not, he has written a very spiritual book.  namaste.

This was a very insightful book. The issues Lanza talks about are fascinating and it makes me query why the principles of Quantum Mechanics are not reported more in the mainstream media. Some amazing facts that would amaze most people! It really changes the way you view physics and the nature of reality. A great read and highly recommended.

What is ultimate reality?  Is Quantum Theory of any help?  The authors  extend some of the results of subatomic physics to our macro-reality world with surprising results.  The book is solid science, careful thought  and pure speculation.  I am about to read it again.  Maybe consciousness really Is the unifying quantity in the universe.

If the human race truly is capable of a deeper spiritual understanding, this book is one that is going to help shape it. Certain aspects of the universe don't exist for no reason, and this book relates things that exist around us permanently to life. Very interesting concept that could be grounds for human evolution in the end.

Interesting and feasible concept, but the author goes overboard in reminding readers again and again why this or that science or non-science supports his premise. Worth the read if you are new to this type of thinking or fed up with physicists creating new dimensions to support science that can never be verified as true.

It was a very interesting read and served to heighten my interest in Biocentrism. As a lay person I found myself in over my head at times,especially in authors summary. Not to take anything from him or imply he is too technical, a brilliant mind is sometimes hard to follow. I am going to read it again .

For me--a science educator and former English professor--this was a "popular" masterpiece. Robert Lanza has earned his spurs in science. It is refreshing for somewhat like him to say where science falls short in telling educated people what they really want to know and where to look elsewhere.

Great piece of work. For those of us who believe in a supreme being, finally a science is evolving that brings understanding to our beliefs. An acknowledgement of the possibility that God is the great observer of the universe (or Gods and universes) creating the reality that man IS.

This is such a fascinating subject, but I had to be encouraged to buy this book as I was afraid it would be over my head.  It IS over my head, but I am SO enjoying it, and it's written in such a way that I understand a good portion of it.  Taking notes and re-reading helps, too.

This is the book that brought it all together for me. Biocentrism was what I had come to believe from various other works and ideas I had come across,. It just wasn't until reading this that I found it so well expressed and put together in one work. Thank you for this work.

This book is easy and fun reading. The author writes clearly and makes important and logical points. The ideas really got me thinking. I'm reading lots of other books that bear on this subject, but "Biocentrism" stands out in terms of its clarity and importance.

Not a new concept for me, but a reminder that there are options other than "God" made it,and/or the "Big Bang" made it. The great possibility that this is an interactive process opens up whole new possibilities with regards to understanding the universe.

How God works is made plausible in this book, though the author would deny that was his intent.  I've personally been thinking along these lines for 10 years and the authors have helped me as a non-physicist, though science guy,  put words and images to my own thoughts.

Great book. Not as easy to understand for a layperson as Barbara Wren's, Cellular Awakening, or The Astonishing Physics of the Mind, by Peter Davis, but I think it should be absorbed in tandem with the other 2 for a more complete comprehension of the related ideas.

An interesting take on the direction science needs to go/ is going, in order to resolve some of the unresolvables of physics. Comes across as a little bit preachy, like the author is trying to hard to make his point, but the science and logic are solid.

This is a fascinating book. I really loved reading it and recommend it to you. I do have to admit however, I was left at the end unsure if I had just read something brilliant or something utterly manufactured. I will leave that decision up to you.

This is a jewel of knowledge. Giving the most complete information to date of how to view the system of the world and beyond.  Although Einstein was important, it is good to see further thinking beyond and references from the new Genius of today.

Very well written and truly fascinating, I believe whole heartedly that consciences is the fundamental basis of all reality. This is one of those books that has better informed me and reinforced in me the beliefs I already have reason to hold.

This is not a particularly easy read, but found ti to be thoroughly digestible, especially if one is seeking an holistic way of understanding the world we live in. I lent my copy to my niece who is taking courses in the biological sciences.

This book is amazing. It "tells" the story most of us, who have given any thought to the " how"of the way life, as a conscious being, operates intuitively understand it. It provides a truth you can feel in your gut and soul.

This book was definitely very eye opening for me. I had never seriously considered the author's theory but he makes a very persuasive case. Although the theory may seem a bit strange at first, it makes complete sense by the end of the book.

Mind blowing.  This book backs up in science what intuition has been saying to me for decades.  The concept it presents is hard to swallow but forces you to think about this universe and consciousness differently.  It's also well written.

Certainly not what you would call light reading. Quantum mechanics and how it pertains to the big questions of existence, consciousness and life. Have to agree with the author that physics is not capable of answering those questions.

Finally, a book other than the Bible explaining how life created the universe, not the other way around.  Lenard in the sitcom Big Bang Theory said it best when asked, "what's new in physics?"  His reply, "nothing!"

I have read numerous books on the topic and I think this one most clearly explains the double slit experiments so the non-physicists can understand them. It is a must read for anyone studying the idea of consciousness and reality.

Out of this world interesting-really makes you think but very philosophical and far reaching as to the evolution of the universe and how we relate to it as 2 legged creatures. Great book and requires brainpower to understand.

Robert Lanza and Bob Berman have written a master work. Biocentrism will be the subject of debate for years to come and will influence the "Grand Unified Theory" once it is discovered. It is good to be here now.

I'm sure not everybody will be convinced by the author, but it's a good read to open yourself to an alternative and intriguing view of the universe we live in. The language used isn't exactly easy to follow though.

Outstanding book. Can be difficult at times to understand his scientific thought process, but he does reel it in at times for the lay person. Very fascinating how he ties in Quantum Physics with consciousness.

The best collection of scientific knowledge dedicated to prove that the universe is in us, not the other way around. Still, like my mother says: the worst blindness belongs to the one who doesn't want to see.

Because it stretched my mind further than heretofore. The idea that I am creating my world when I am conscious is very compelling, the idea that the same world disappears when I am not conscious is difficult.

I thought this book was amazing.  It Kept my attention and i was truly intrigued by the experiments and examples he provided. This book has changed my view on  life and I will never experience life the same.
Robert Lanza writes with the right combination of scholarly scientific acumen and down to earth explanation about the deepest mysteries of reality..

Interesting theory.  Could have used a bit more hard evidence.  Or the names of some other believers.  In reading other current scientists I do not see them stating anything like this.  Loved the book.

Helps explain how nothing existed until the observer existed, and the observer is the creator of everything that exist, including the observer themselves. Time is an illusion, a perception, a creation.
I liked this book. The author uses strong stories and a great idea (the universe is the result of consciousness) as a. Red line. What I miss is the practicality of this idea, what can we be more now?
Splendid book. The authors deserve the best credits for making this masterpiece project. The book provides you with clear picture of interference between quantum physics and consciousness. Great job!
You don't have to accept new ideas but it pays to entertain them, digest them, and be  informed and pensive for them. This book is worth the read.
I've read stacks of theology, philosophy, and QT books. For my reality, this study makes the most sense.  Of course there are lots of naysayers, but on this side of death, it really doesn't matter.
Thoroughly enjoyed the ideas presented and appreciate the effort to state things so that everyone can easily understand. Robert Lanza is an excellent writer who knows how to present an idea well.
It's not the best written book you'll find. The idea is cool and I love hearing new ideas of looking at the world from intelligent, creative people. Definitely worth the read. Thought provoking.
This book takes more than a handful of complicated thought provoking ideas and explains them in clear and interesting ways. Found myself reading way more at a sitting than I intended every time.
presents an opposing point of view from String Theory, 9-dimension universe, parallel universe and many theories that are impossible to prove or observed but were taken as if they were reality.
It's an effort to read but worth it.  It would be nice to have a physics background but understanding the universe from a quantum physics point of view is slow reading for me but soooo rich!
Has most everything you will find discussed in a book about physics with a biological twist.  It's good, but could have contained more material aside from the authors personal experiences.
It's not easy to read about quantum physics after 50 years of not thinking about it, only to find I've been struggling thru it to be told it's not right (!) but still, I'm glad to be told.
Part of the missing puzzle.  So far, I adore this book.  You may find gaps in your perspective bonding to the whole and what a fulfilling way to exist....a much needed drink of water.
This book has some concepts and ideas that make you wonder. An interesting read for sure. It just might change your whole perception of everything you think you know. Check it out.
Physics is not enough to explain consciousness.  Time is not linear.  Is life even "real"?  Read for yourself and decide.
The truth will set you free. Science is finally catching up with the truth presented many years ago by "A Course in Miracles"
Very well written. It makes a complex question understandable to any careful reader. Anyone interested in the origins of the Universe will find this book well worth reading.
Interesting concept but i was expecting more in terms of explaining biocentrism as an alternative to current theories such as big bang, multiple or infinite universes, etc.
Very interesting read.  Has left me with some profound thoughts on consciousness and how and when it begins.  When is that first "moment" of self realization?
The science of the physical world cannot be divorced from the consciousness that interprets it.  This excellent book will definitely challenge you view of reality.
This book's provocative ideas drew me to it, but the beautiful storytelling kept me interested. It truly changed the way I see our universe and our place in it.
If you have an open mind to new possibilities of creation and purpose for the beginning and existence of the universe, this is a great perspective. I loved it.

One of the easiest and most fascinating volumes in mass market new science books. It is well worth reading for almost anyone. I did not give it five stars only because the 19th chapter (Death and Eternity) seems poorly developed and out of sync with the rest of the book. Notwithstanding that quibble, read this book!
Totally changes your way of thinking. Everything seems much clearer. Just started.  But I know. I will reading it again. Thers so much to absorb.  Thank you
Despite a lot of physics data thrown at you still understandable for non scientists. If you are into Indian philosophy or non dualism this book is for you!
Very engaging and convincing. Lanza makes a compelling case for his theory of biocentrism. Anybody interested in consciousness should read this book.
Very interesting and thought provoking book.  The author's writing is not too technical an easy to follow.  But some of the ideas are mind boggling.
I loved the concepts this book presented but have to admit the more detailed scientific explanations in later chapters lost me!  Mind blowing!
Messrs Berman and Lanza have mad a good attempt to explain the theory of Biocentrism. However, the piece feels as incomplete as the theory.
One of the most interesting books I have  read . I am re-reading it . I'd like to write some poems on the feelings and ideas it generates
I liked it because it was different view on consciousness and way the whole universe is all connected. I would recommend it good reading.
If you have a science background, you might enjoy this book. Deep exploration of the physical world and the unexplained consciousness.
This book is refreshing and thought provoking. I love the author's perspective on the universe. Definitely recommend it to my friends.
I liked the ideas... I wondered about his choices from his personal experience and wonder whether or not they supported the ideas..
some thought provoking stuff. to me this seems like an introduction to a more elaborate work in the future. hope this is the case!
I Love books that challenge the normal theories and this book certainly does that! It reflects thoughts I have had for many years.
The idea is great but please, do not take it literally! There is much more to it if you really expand "Consciousness"
Excellent reading and an outstanding introduction to the quantum physics and a true understanding of what life is all about.
Well written. And makes more sense than "Religion".A very plausible at the same time mind bending look at creation .
An excellent book, well worth reading and study by those who have a definite interest in this type of material and subject.
Everyone from atheist to Zen Buddhist should read this.  The reading is a little heavy in places but well worth the effort.
I very much enjoyed this book.  I enjoyed the writer.  There were lots of interesting ideas and it was easy to understand.
A mind opener in topics like Time and Space. A definite read to know more about Quantum Theory and its impact on us.
It's a novel idea. It weaves what we already know with the context by which what remains unknown can be understood.
A thought provoking read that finally starts to put the pieces in place to develop a working theory of everything.

This is a book that will probably change your mind about the nature of the universe even if you cannot agree with everything suggested. Biocentrism offers a sea change in how we think about consciousness and how this affects everything we see and experience.  The idea that biology and life influence our perception of the world is at the very least a fascinating alternative to  religion or atheism.  The last chapter asks "Where Do We Go From here?"  Although no final solution is proposed the hope that a multidisciplinary approach will incorporate biocentrism is upplifting.
Very interesting concept. It makes this very complicated subject easy to understand and sometimes even fun!
i love this book taught me a lot  most of the things i already new from eastern thought but very good read

Authors, Berman and Lanza, want you the change everything you think you know about the world around you. Their persuasion is gentle and their analogies are fairly compelling, but the conclusions are far over the heads of laypersons. These ideas are simply too revolutionary and counterintuitive to gain traction at this particular place in "time" among the general population. Ultimately, though, it was not written for us, but rather for the small population of thinkers capable of grasping these concepts. That being said,  glad I read it.
Amazing Book.  Great Concepts In Which To Build Your Own Conclusions.  Sorry For The Caps.

This book is a delightful read. What Dr. Lanza calls Biocentrism, Physicist Amit Goswami calls Monistic Idealism. This book does a fab job at lucidly illustrating the quantum experiments that defy materalistic assumptions and tie reality to the partcipating minds of the observors. Quantum experiments and quantum mathematics seem to be literally pointing to an Idealistic/Biocentric universe. It seems we no longer live in a cold and dead universe, but rather one that is fundamentally animate and alive! Or as the biologist Rupert Sheldrake would put it, the universe appears to be more like a developing living organism rather than a machine!
A really stimulating mind bender to provoke much thought and discussion with friends.
Read it only if you are at least 2 steps far ahead from a religiocentric universe!!!
Easy to read and thoughtful analysis. I'm not sure I agree with the overall premise.
A different way of looking at reality that is not based on science or myth .

I'm not sure what I just read, but it was awesome. If half of these things are true, it seems the after life, are transdemensional existence is way better than the cubical existence I am currently living. Something to look forward to.
Modern Science meets Catches up with Jane Roberts' Sethianism.  Superb
Eye opening...good read...I highly recommend it. Read with open mind.

Finally, a mainstream scientist finds that science need not be constrained by materialism in understanding the world.  Rather, materialism is an outdated narrative on the path to understanding that the mind is at the root of reality.

Just a thought I have believed for a very very long time electrons in our body have to go somewhere, and I never read a book about this subject. Biocentrism just blow me away, but this is a thought... if the electrons leave our body and turns into heat energy , then heat energy  turns into static....and  from what I understand static can be stored...why can't we trap that static at the moment it's release when we died....and if we store this static what is next...........
Excellent book, and it has a very interesting and new theory. It's also not a dry text book type of read.

Robert Lanza does a tremendous job of blending biographical background with a presentation of a revolutionary view of the universe that is about to stand traditional science on its head.  Dr. Lanza is a scientist of the first order and a very engaging writer.  Don't miss this book!
Amazing, beautiful theory of the universe, life, and consciousness.
Compelling argument for existence through the consciousness lens.

An interesting read, the author develops his ideas of consciousness as being the bases of life and perception.  The style is a little too authoritarian and dismissive of other schools of thought for my liking, but I would recommend it to anyone interested in this fascinating topic, the author provides more pieces to the puzzle.
fantastic read, really opened my eyes to a new view of reality
Berman is on to something big.  I would more works like this.

I had heard about biocentrism but had no idea what it was about. It's a very original explanation of the mystery of consciousness. The reading is very easy and never pedantic, I have found very interesting especially the first chapters about quantum theory and the role of the ​conscious observer.
Great book, well presented ideas.  Highly recommended.

This brilliant book will open new worlds to the reader and expand the mind beyond all boundaries of objective science.  The writer opens an enticing portal into the virtual world of quantum consciousness. I trust we will hear more from this genius mind in the future!
A very interesting book on a very interesting subject
Interesting theory. Explained in a very simple way.

A thoroughly enjoyable romp through consciousness.  Each  chapter escorts the reader down the aisle of what seems real and what is real.  Leave your preconceptions at the door, you are on the good ship  consciousness and we're not stopping, ever.
so in depth yet concise.. simply invigorating !
A very thought provoking essay about reality.
why is there no Whispersync for this book?

A beautifully crafted look into a future here and now when the essential role of consciousness to all subsequent experience will be understood and accepted. Science has come full circle from the Sanskrit.
Interesting philosophy...time will tell.
outstanding .  well written for laymen
Love, love,  love this book.  I will be reading it multiple times and would suggest it to any one with deep questions in search of answers backed by scientific research.  Just Amazing!
A book worth reading...probably twice
Really interesting and enlightening.

This is an odd amalgam of personalized reminices that describe a poor boy's aspiration and achievements and a popularization of a rather extreme version of the anthrpomporphic prinicple in physics,i.e. the presence of an observer is necessary for the universe to exist as it does.In its former themes,it is mawkish and self indulgent;in  its latter it is shallow and unpersuasive.In his science explication the author  regularly approaches the reducio ad absurdum of solipcism and ignores its consequence.One wonders for whom he wrote the book since he appears completely persuaded that nobody else exists as anything but his idea of them.
Very thought provoking. It breaks down the dilemma physics has with understanding and ignoring conciousness. I can't wait to read it again.
Informative book regarding biomecenyrism, but sort of strange how the author included personal stories. Overall pretty good, but not great.
Great book! Something definitely to think about. I like the scientific take on this topic. As an engineer myself, this makes sense to me.
Best book I have read that connects science and spirituality.  Easy to read and understand.  Excellent use of symbolism and comparisons.

I could have given this book 5 star if the author had eliminated all the parts about his personal life/achievements/successes. He spent pages after pages writing about his past life (and now he is supposedly a successful professor), and almost made this book a self-help, fiction. Also, he has to remember that some people will pay to read his book. So, please have some respect towards your customers, and let them read a non-fiction as the title seems to suggest (if they wanted to read a self-help or a fiction, they would have picked up a completely different book. Nobody wants to read your past life when talking about science). Also, please don't disregard all the scientists who actually made today's life style possible (they may have made mistakes along the way, but remember you stand on their shoulders). From the outset it is clear that Robert Lanza does not understand much of the scientific studies and principals that he claims to support his theory. Furthermore he skews the view of modern physics by claiming that it is caught up in unprovable theories and fantasies and even compares it to religion. He takes shots at attempts at unifying theories like string theory for example, he rants about how theories of extra dimensions are unprovable, which by the way, is untrue. The book is filled with factual errors, wild assumptions and leaps of logic from his examples of established scientific principles to his unrelated and outlandish theories. I recommend  to anyone thinking about reading this book to first read Brian Greenes "Fabric of the Cosmos". Had i not read it first perhaps i too would have been impressed by Robert Lanzas seemingly authoritative take on the universe. Furthermore much of the book is comprised of long diatribes of Lanzas childhood that really have nothing to do with his theory. Also the principles of Biocentrism are redundant and erroneous. A good example of how meagre lanzas understanding of physics is, is how he asserts that space is not a physical entity but a mathematical construct used to describe the actions of objects relative to each other. This Machian view has been disproved with the creation of Einsteins general relativity and quantum physics. Another is how he grossly exaggerates the effect of probability waves on the macroscopic scale. The probability waves of the particles that make up any object above the quantum scale are so minuscule that they do not have the slightest effect on the structure of an object between being observed and unobserved. I find it actually quite sickening that such a book could be published without proper fact checking, as if it is read by someone without prior knowledge of physics then it could be quite convincing.

Although it is apparent that Lanza is brilliant and his writing style is  superb, I find his logic and use of scientific data are stretched into the realm  of fantasy.  I completely agree that the brain and consciousness are entwined and should be included in the Grand Theory of Everything. On the other hand, to make a "quantum leap" from the "double slit" and "entanglement" experiments to a theory that consciousness is the cause of everything in the universe is Harry Potter fantasy.

I don't think Lanza knows what he's talking about, really. His idea is that we exist "because we're possible", in a nutshell - because the universe is one big quantum system, it exists in all physically possible states in a simultaneous superposition. Therefore, we exist simply because the arrangement of atoms that makes us up is a possible arrangement of the universe. The idea can be compounded on greatly, but not the way Lanza did. He takes this interesting idea in quantum physics (which is not as new as he insists), and turns it into his semi-religious "life created itself". The book is very repetitive, mostly made up of stories of him "connecting" with other life and realizing there must be some bigger picture. This is entirely a quantum-physical idea, yet he devotes just one chapter (more like half) to it. Don't buy.

The idea of light being the fastest anything can travel is disspelled, is one of the many notions that science is trying to wrestle with. Biocentrism says it is because of us that we don't understand it and when we think we do, another notion comes to challenge it. The limitations of homo sapien sapiens is also the limitations of science. The key concepts of science and our misunderstandings of them are well-presented in this book. Readers of Owen Barfield's SAVING THE APPEARANCES will be reminded of its opening pages.  Barfield has much more to offer those who are interested in the correlative relationship between consciousness and nature.  Lanza argues that science shows there was never a time when an external, dumb, physical universe existed, or that life sprang from it at a later date; any universe that could have preceded consciousness only existed in a state of probability waves.  His arguments usefully challenge our habits of thought, but he's probably afflicted by what Barfield calls a residue of unresolved positivism (shown, e.g., in his use of "brain" and "mind" as interchangeables).  I think the best use of this book could be to prepare readers for the challenge of reading SAVING THE APPEARANCES.  There, Barfield deals with implications that Lanza doesn't seem to be aware of, e.g. with regard to the "prehistory" of the earth.  Barfield explores language as a way to search into the evolution of consciousness in this book and other writings.  Dale Nelson's essay "The Troubled Legacy of Owen Barfield," published in TOUCHSTONE magazine, is an introduction to the late British thinker.  See Lanza's essay "Biocentrism" in Discover magazine May 2009, and Tim Folger's article about John Wheeler (anthropic principle) in Discover for June 2002, for introductions to ideas basic to the present book.
